page.title: 18SHOTTS CUSTOMS FOLKLORE
page.content: {Bartram Shotts} Shotts lies on the line of the Great Road which from and before Roman times has been the main East West route. In the 15th century the road became dangerous due to the activities of a notorious giant highwayman known as Bartram Shotts.A reward was offered by King James IV for his capture ,dead or alive. He was ambushed by the young laird of Muirhead as he lay drinking at Kate's Well,named after St.Catherine. The laird hamstrung him as he lay there ,cut off his head and carried it to the king. This story is one doubtful explanation for the origin of the name "Shotts".
